These phenomena have exacerbated numerous challenges, especially in the urban realm, prompting the global community to seek sustainable solutions. This motivated the introduction of the 17 SDGs in 2015. Long before the launch of the SDGs, there was an interest in the global arena in adopting smart solutions and technologies for solving global issues (Anthopoulos, 2017; Sharifi, Allam, Feizizadeh, & Ghamari, 2021). Protagonists of smart cities argue that smart solutions could solve a majority of urban challenges, with some arguing that they have the potential to accelerate the achievement of the SDGs (Joia & Kuhl, 2019).

This systematic review demonstrated that responsible development and implementation of smart city solutions and technologies could contribute to the progress toward sustainable development goals. Most studies examining the linkages have been published in the past two years, indicating that this field is emergent. Although indirect linkages between all SDGs and smart city solutions can be established, the analysis showed that the focus is mainly on SDGs 11, 12, 7, 6, and 4. More work on other SDGs is, therefore, needed. A key finding is a bias toward reporting positive contributions. This has also been highlighted in other studies related to SDGs (Vinuesa et al., 2020). As Table 1 shows, among other things, the benefits include accelerating economic growth, improving efficiency, enhancing managerial practices, strengthening innovation, and raising citizen awareness. Overall, in the literature, the benefits of smart cities outweigh the trade-offs. However, we found that potential trade-offs and challenges related to privacy and cyber security, costs of infrastructure upgrading, the risk of the increased cost of living, the digital divide and lack of skills, rebound effects, biased decision-making, reproduction of social biases, and the limited legal setup can also occur.

Overcoming the challenges requires government interventions and multi-scale governance mechanisms to ensure balanced growth and avoid disproportionate impacts on some societal groups. Developing standard and interoperable formats for secure data collection and exchange is one solution that could offer opportunities for the engagement of different groups and stakeholders in smart cities, thereby enhancing the prospect of contribution to SDGs (Liaqat et al., 2021). Stakeholder engagement and consultation could ensure that smart solutions can meet the needs of people. A key challenge is the potential misuse of AI and the risk of biased decision-making toward certain societal groups. Indeed, many smart solutions and technologies, such as those based on AI, are still in their incipient stages. Effective governance and regulatory measures are needed to ensure they will not undermine the achievement of SDGs (Truby, 2020). Preventing this requires transparency with algorithms and training programs (Truby, 2020), government interventions to ensure that AI is human-centered (Mhlanga, 2022), developing ethical standards and regular auditing to ensure compliance with them, and measures to regulate surveillance technologies and practices of governments and corporations (Truby, 2020).

The COVID-19 crisis and other syndemics will have far-reaching implications for surveillance society, with potential implications for achieving SDGs. As Kitchin (2020) argued, this crisis âwas an opportunity for the state to further roll-out and normalize surveillance technologies and there is little sense that the tracking implemented there will be rolled-back post-crisis.â The surveillance system deployed to combat the COVID-19 pandemic will become part of the ânew normalâ in digitally monitoring and governing societies. This may result in mass surveillance practiced mainly by big tech companies and in legitimating tyranny by democratic states, thereby eroding civil liberties related to privacy and democracy. At the core of the ânew normalâ is the intensification of the hyper-connectivity, datafication, algorithmization, and platformization of the social organization resulting from all kinds of interactions and activities that citizens perform as part of everyday life in smart cities. Platformization refers to âthe penetration of infrastructures, economic processes, and governmental frameworks of digital platforms in different economic sectors and spheres of life, as well as the reorganization of cultural practices and imaginations around these platformsâ (Poell et al., 2019). Platforms as an ideological formation are associated with smart cities and sharing economy (Barta & Neff, 2016). They steer both platform-based user interactions as well as economic transactions (Poell et al., 2019), which are associated with the governance dimension of platformization (Gorwa, 2019). Major companies have actively repurposed their platforms and data to tackle the COVID-19 pandemic and potential future syndemics. For instance, Google, Meta, Apple, and Microsoft have developed initiatives to monitor the effects of interventionist measures globally and facilitate contact tracing. They have also generated and shared real-time location and mobility data (Brandom & Robertson, 2020; Kitchin, 2020). However, some criticisms underscore the concerns surrounding the involvement of these big companies in public health measures and the potential implications for governance and autonomy. For instance, some scholars criticized the Google-Apple Exposure Notification (GAEN) framework for promoting a technocratic solution and challenging state sovereignty (Mann et al., 2022; Mann, Mitchell, Foth, & Anastasiu, 2020).

Overall, the emergence of these solutionist technologies has led to the development of new approaches in management and governance. In fact, the utilization of surveillance technologies has made social and spatial sorting more commonplace. A rigid techno-dystopian stance is one of the socio-spatial implications of platform-mediated urban everyday life and urban futures (StrÃ¼ver & Bauriedl, 2022). Indeed, the new routines of social and spatial sorting have âthe potential to permanently shift the nature of governmentality and to also act as a pathway towards authoritarian forms of governance where technology is used to actively impose the will of the state onto citizensâ (Kitchin, 2020). This has entrenched the wrong idea that the techno-managerialist mode of governing by code in smart cities is the only option to go, with no alternative scenario. It has been promoted as the most effective and efficient way to manage citizens through the systemic collection and algorithmic processing of data for decision-making purposes that exclude political action. These forms of algorithmic technocratic governance are set to cement and normalize the governmental logic of capture and control instead of surveillance and discipline. Regulatory frameworks and transparency of algorithms are, therefore, essential and should be prioritized. There are also examples of more citizen-centric and community-oriented governance alternatives that should be followed to ensure smart solutions contribute to creating livable and sustainable cities (Foth, Anastasiu, Mann, & Mitchell, 2021; Mattern & De, 2021; Powell, 2021).

With its multifarious consequences, it is evident that the impacts of the COVID-19 crisis will not fade any time soon and will be felt in our ways of living and working in cities. In fact, it is already shown that the pandemic has slowed down progress toward SDGs (De Las Heras et al., 2020a, 2020b). This calls for the need to critically investigate or engage with smart urbanism regarding how it may shape urban futures and its evolution to platform urbanism and its development in response to this crisis. It is also important to address issues such as social exclusion, discrimination, dataveillance, geosurveillance, privacy erosion, mind control, and democratic decay (Bibri & Allam, 2022). Especially this crisis has worsened the effects of big tech companies getting involved in data policies and public trust in data governance through the accelerated adoption of digital technologies (Li, Ma, & Wu, 2022). Consequently, from an ethical perspective, âmost of the policies, regulations, legislations, and auditing mechanisms created and established in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic are of a destructive nature and directed towards stripping away people from their natural and constitutional rightsâ (Bibri & Allam, 2022). This review calls for a better investigation of these issues and their implications for achieving SDGs in future studies. This will be essential to ensure that the economic ambitions pursued via the deployment of smart cities will be aligned with SDGs. Other key research gaps related to the interlinkages between smart cities and SDGs that need to be addressed in future research include: implications of platformization for achieving SDGs; trade-offs for understudied SDGs such as SDG No. 14 and SDG NO. 17; and trade-offs beyond issues related to costs, equity, and energy efficiency. Also, it is important to mention that interlinkages between smart cities and SDGs are not just limited to co-benefits and trade-offs. Synergies and conflicts are two other important types of interactions that should also be examined. Synergies could occur when the simultaneous implementation of smart city solutions and SDG efforts could lead to greater benefits than when they are implemented separately. In contrast, conflict, while not common, refers to a situation when the simultaneous implementation of these two could be difficult. Examining synergies and conflicts allow for obtaining a more comprehensive understanding of interactions between smart cities and SDGs. Finally, as existing research is mainly conceptual and theoretical, it is important to do more empirical research on the interactions between smart cities and SDGs.
